section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Alphabet Cards, Activity Cards

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story From Our Hands and we saw the letters Pp, Tt, Vv, and Zz.
This is uppercase P and this is lowercase p. Which letter makes the /p/ sound you hear in the words penguin and peach?
This is uppercase T and this is lowercase t. Which letter makes the /t/ sound you hear in the words tiger and turtle?
This is uppercase V and this is lowercase v. Which letter makes the /v/ sound you hear in the words vest and vase?
This is uppercase Z and this is lowercase z. Which letter makes the /z/ sound you hear in the words zebra and zipper?
Today we are going to look at pictures of fruits and vegetables. We are going to talk about letters and sounds.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card at a time. Ask the questions on the back of the card, offering help as needed.
Extend Ask the question at the bottom of the card to extend thinking.
Repeat Continue until the children have seen all the cards.
Match and Add Then have children find the pairs of pictures that begin with the same sound. Ask: What sound do both these words begin with?
Practice Writing Letters Have children practice writing Pp, Tt, Vv, and Zz. Next to each letter, ask them to draw a picture that reminds them of the letter’s sound.
Help children identify each target sound by saying the words slowly. Guide children to say the letter and sound correctly, using the Alphabet Cards as support.

Challenge children to name only foods that begin with the letters Pp and Tt. Some examples may be pizza, popcorn, potato chips, pretzels, peas, pears, pineapples; turkey, tomatoes, tamales, tacos, tempura.

Be aware that some children whose first language is Spanish may pronounce the letters Ss and Zz alike and the letters Bb and Vv alike. Take extra time, as needed, to review the sounds those letters make in English, both in isolation and in the context of a picture word.

To help children with auditory discrimination challenges, exaggerate the movements of your mouth as you form each letter sound, being mindful of your tongue and lip positions. Do this while saying the sound in isolation and again as you say the sound within the picture word. Invite children to move their mouths in the same way as they make the letter sound.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Paper and markers, play clay

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the informational text From Our Hands. We talked about and shared information about the book.
When we have ideas we like to talk about them and share them with others.
Today we’re going to see how we do a fun activity and share our ideas. Today, we’re going to make letters using play clay.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Demonstrate how to form a straight line, a half circle, and a circle. Then model how to make a letter of the alphabet using play clay.
Set Up Distribute play clay and paper.
Ask Ask children to begin forming the first letter of their names.
Repeat Invite children to continue forming each letter of their names.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: How did you feel when you did this activity? What made this activity fun? What are some other things you like to make with play clay?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Some children, especially those with long names, may find it overwhelming to make all the letters. Limit the activity for them to make their first initial or nickname.
Challenge children to start creating an alphabet using play dough. Set aside time each day for them to work on their alphabets until they complete them.
Pair multilingual learners with English speaking friends to encourage more conversation. Children may gain some new vocabulary this way.
Have children stop several times while making letters. Breaking the activity into chunks can give children more guidance in following through with the activity.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Alphabet Cards, Magnetic Letters, Alphabet Books
Connect to Large Group Today we read the story From Our Hands and we saw words with the letters P, T, V, and Z.
Review Pp, Tt, Vv, and Zz Sounds As you review each letter, ask a child to place the matching Magnetic Letter next to each Alphabet Book. Ask the group to say the sound that each letter makes.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we will look at Alphabet Books that have many words that start with Pp, Tt, Vv, and Zz. We will say those words, then think of other words that start with those same sounds.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Place the Alphabet Cards on the table, arranged in sets of matching first sounds. Magnetic Letters for P, T, V, Z should also be on the table, separate from the Alphabet Books.

Ask Ask one child to hold up the Magnetic Letter P. Ask another child to say the sound that the letter P makes. Then have a third child select the Alphabet Book that corresponds with the letter P. Show several pictures in the book and ask different children to name the items, then make the /p/ sound. Then, ask children to think of items at school or home that begin with the /p/ sound.
Repeat Continue the activity, using the Magnetic Letters and Alphabet Books for the letters Tt, Vv, and Zz.

Practice Producing Words with the Same Beginning Sound Have children work in pairs, taking turns to name other pictures in the Alphabet Books and repeating the beginning sound after they name the picture.

Do this activity with just one letter at a time, setting other Alphabet Books and Magnetic Letters aside. Model producing several words that begin with the same sound as the given pair of words. Make the beginning sounds of a new word and ask children to finish the word.
Write these alliterative sentences for children and have them illustrate them; Pat paints pots. Tara has ten toys. Vic visits Vera. Zebra zips and zooms.

Be aware that some children whose first language is Spanish may pronounce the letters Ss and Zz alike and the letters Bb and Vv alike. Take extra time, as needed, to review the sounds those letters make in English, both in isolation and in the context of a picture word.

Assist children by beginning with yes or no questions about the card, then encourage the student to model sentences after you, such as: This is a zebra. Does zebra begin with the /z/ sound ? (yes) Say this after me: Zebra begins with a /z/ sound. (child repeats).

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Vocabulary Cards, Activity Cards

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the Big Chart “Let’s Make Fruit Salad” and talked about the ingredients in a fruit salad.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Vocabulary Use the Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words fruit salad and ingredients.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will pretend we are mixing different ingredients together to make a fruit salad. We will use different picture cards to talk about the ingredients and directions, then we will pretend to prepare and eat our delicious fruit salad!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Place the cards of the mixing bowl and spoon face up. Keep the remaining cards face down.

Ask Begin by holding up the picture with the mixing bowl and ask the question on the back of the card. Then, replace the card, face up, on the desk. Repeat with the mixing spoon picture card. Give each child a chance to pretend to use the mixing spoon card to stir. Then, show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering support or extra challenge as needed. Place the card face up under the picture of the mixing bowl. Ask volunteers to pretend to mix each new ingredient as it is added to the mixing bowl.
Repeat Continue the activity using all of the picture cards.

Talk About Making Fruit Salad How did following the directions help you learn about making fruit salad? Examples might include the importance of gathering and preparing the ingredients and then mixing them together in the bowl.

To simplify, begin with each picture card face up under the mixing bowl and spoon cards. Name each item, asking children to repeat after you. Then, describe each item as you add it to the mixing bowl and stir it, supporting children to join in the conversation.
Work together to write a sentence about each ingredient, focusing on adding some description to each sentence. Encourage children to assist with end punctuation for each sentence.

Children might recognize the fruits but not yet know the English word for each. Encourage children to name the ingredients using words in their home language. After they do so, share the English word for the fruits and talk about whether they sound similar or different to the words in other languages.

Assist children by beginning with yes or no questions about the fruit salad activity, then follow up to encourage the child to model sentences after you, such as, Is this a banana? (yes) Say this after me: This is a banana. (child repeats)
